prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Observation of a point-like source at redshift 2.405. Excellent multi-lambda coverage: sensitive near-IR spectra NTT/SOFI, high-resolution UVES echelle spectra, significant photometric coverage to perform SED fitting.
Our immediate aims are to observe CO(3-2) lines and to obtain accurate host masses.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our immediate aims are to observe CO lines and to obtain accurate host masses. The L'_CO(1-0) is commonly used to translate measured CO luminosities into H_2 masses using the conversion factor alpha_CO (Carilli & Walter 2013). Given that the CO(1-0) line is not directly observable for our targets, we thus focus on the lowest J transition that is accessible at these redshifts, i.e. CO(3-2). In this way we are less dependent on the conversion factor assumption. In order to evaluate the required sensitivity, we computed the bolometric luminosity of these QSOs from their B-band (McClure & Dunlop 2004). Following Wang et al.(2011), we infer the associated FIR luminosity as log L_FIR=0.62 log L_bol+3.9. The FIR luminosities are likely too faint for individual continuum detections. The associated CO(1-0) luminosity can be derived as log L_FIR=1.37 log L'_CO(1-0) -1.74 (Carilli & Walter 2013). These luminosities are converted into CO(3-2) luminosities by assuming an M82-like excitation ladder (Weiss et al. 2007). Finally, line flux densities are derived by assuming a fiducial line width of 300 km s-1. We conservatively assume a factor of ~2 lower fluxes to account for the significant scatter in the above assumed relations. The expected total source line fluxes are in the range 2-4 mJy. In order to estimate the sensitivity, we have divided the total source line flux to the resolution element (i.e. 4) and we have required a detection significance in the range 3-5 sigma. We also required the extended configuration (C34-7, 0.4 arcsec resolution) in order to properly map the molecular emission of the host galaxy. NOTE ON CONFIGURATION: We would like to reach 0.4" resolution and thus ask for bservations in the C34-7. However, observations in C34-6 would also be acceptable. CALIBRATION: Default calibration is requested. BANDPASS ACCURACY: No special bandpass accuracy is needed.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to use ALMA to obtain sensitive and spatially resolved CO observations in order to measure molecular gas masses and characterize the gas kinematics for the 4 brightest QSOs on the sky. These targets have the most massive black holes, and hence are the most conducive to perform resolved kinematic studies with ALMA. All have precise near-IR systemic redshifts, the most accurate black hole (BH) masses, and are chosen to have archival high-resolution optical-UV spectra, that will allow us to simultaneously study the kinematics of ionized (absorption) and molecular gas components. The proposed observations will address several key science goals: 1) Investigate merger driven fueling scenarios for QSOs, by searching for possible kinematic offsets between the BH location (near-IR) and gas-rich host detected in CO emission; 2) Constrain AGN feedback in the QSO environment by studying the molecular gas kinematics (mm), ionized gas (optical) and the BH (near-IR); 3) Study the scaling relations between BH and molecular gas mass. Together, the measurements will provide critical insights linking BH accretion and star formation in a QSO sample with outstanding multi-lambda coverage.
